creditline: Collection of Yvonne and Gabriel P. Weisberg
description: cat. 54; woman at L shoveling near well and barn; man at R raking; house at R in background; beige paper; light brown mat with simple light stained wood frame
medium: Brush and black ink, ink wash, charcoal, watercolor, and gouache with red crayon on tan paper laid down on board
text:
In 1905 Charles Milcendeau purchased a plot of land in the heart of the Vend√©e marshes near his hometown of Soullans (but kept a flat in Paris). The property included a series of small, low-lying thatched houses called bourrines, along with some stables that he converted into a studio. In this drawing, he depicted his own bourrine, with its arched doorway, at the far left. The studio and other outbuildings
lie to the right, beyond the two laborers. Despite this traditional subject matter, Milcendeau was experimental and forward-looking in his approach, combining various mediums including ink, watercolor, gouache, crayon, and charcoal, all worked with consummate skill.
title: Milcendeau's House at Bois Durand
